front.title: On-Path delay Data-field for In Situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM)

abstract.t: This document defines a Data-Field In Situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) architecture for on-path delay information. This Data-Field is registered as a new entry in the "IOAM Trace-Type" registry.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Network operators need to mesure the On-Path delay accross their network to monitor the proper functionning of their infrastructure and applications.

This document proposes an IOAM Trace-type Data-field and its associated Bit-field to export delay measurements. The delay measurements can be obtained based on the "timestamp seconds" and "timestamp fractions" Trace-type Data-fields defined in using a Passport-mode approach. In Postcard-mode, the delay can be obtained using the timestamp extensions defined in .
describes the suggested solution and describes the proposed IOAM Data-Field.

describes how the delay can be computed using the existing Trace-Type Data-Fields and describes how the delay can be calculated using a timestamp extension.

section.title: Using IOAM Trace-Option
section.t: In Passport-mode, telemetry data is added to the data-plane packet at each node of the IOAM-domain and all collected metrics are exported by the decapsulation node.

Pre-allocated Trace Option-type and Incremental Trace Option-type, as defined in Section 4.4 of , is used to transport the different metrics. The exported metrics are defined by the Bit-field IOAM Trace-Type as defined in Section 4.4.1 of .

To compute the delay at the transit and decapsulation node, a timestamp reference from the encapsulation node needs to be added. Bit 2 (timestamp seconds) and Bit 3 (timestamp fraction) from the IOAM Trace-type field can be used for this purpose and at each node, the on-path delay can be computed using the delay from the encapsulation node and the current node.
To export the on-path delay, a new bit in the IOAM Trace-Type Bit-field is needed. defines the Data-Field.
To export the on-path delay metrics, can be used to collect raw IOAM data.

section.title: Using IOAM DEX Option
section.t: In Postcard-mode, telemetry data is exported at the transit nodes and decapsulation node of the IOAM domain. The telemetry data can be aggregated at each node before being exported to a collector.

DEX Option-type, as defined in , is used for this purpose. The exported telemetry data is defined in IOAM Trace-Type Bit-field. The export of the on-path delay is based on the On-Path Delay field defined in .

The timestamp reference needs to be added to the IOAM DEX Option-type header. defines an extension to allow adding the timestamp in the encapsulation node. Bit 2 (timestamp seconds) and Bit 3 (timestamp fraction) from the IOAM DEX Extension-Flags, defined in , are used to add this time reference. At each transit and decapsulation node, the difference between the timestamp in the header and the current timestamp is computed.
To export the aggregated on-path delay metrics, IPFIX can used with . This allows aggregation before the export. Raw IOAM DEX Option data can also be exported using .

section.title: On-Path delay Data-field
section.t: The "On-Path Delay" field is a 4-octet unsigned integer field. This field indicates the on-path delay between the encapsulation node and the transit or decapsulation node mesured in microseconds.
The Data-Field is allocated by IANA, as defined in .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security considerations for the IOAM Trace-Type and IOAM DEX Option-type are defined in and in . This document adds no additional security considerations.
